Unit 1: Introduction to Statistics

Lecture 1: What is Statistics?

Lecture 2: Probability Redux

Law of Large Numbers, Central Limit Theorem

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) random variables (r.v.). Let μ=\E[X]\mu = \E[X]μ=\E[X] the expectation and σ2=\V[X]\sigma^2 = \V[X]σ2=\V[X] the variance of these random variables.

We define the sample average of our XiX_iXi​ as:

Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\bar{X}_n = \frac1n \sum_{i=1}^nX_iXˉn​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

Law of Large Numbers (LLN):

(1.1)Xˉn\conv\P,a.s.μ\tag{1.1} \bar{X}_n \conv{\P, a.s.}\muXˉn​\conv\P,a.s.μ(1.1)

Where \P\P\P designs convergence in probability and a.s.a.s.a.s. convergence almost surely.

Central Limit Theorem (CLT):

(1.2)nXˉn−μσ\convdN(0,1)\tag{1.2} \sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu}{\sigma} \convd \mathcal{N}(0, 1)n​σXˉn​−μ​\convdN(0,1)(1.2)

Equivalently, we also have:

n(Xˉn−μ)\convdN(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n - \mu) \convd \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xˉn​−μ)\convdN(0,σ2)

If nnn is not large enough to apply the CLT, we have Hoeffding's inequality. If X∈[a,b]X \in [a, b]X∈[a,b] almost surely, then

\P[∣Xˉn−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp⁡(−2nε2(b−a)2)\P[|\bar{X}_n - \mu| \geq \varepsilon] \leq 2\exp\left(-\frac{2n\varepsilon^2}{(b-a)^2}\right)\P[∣Xˉn​−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp(−(b−a)22nε2​)

Properties of normal distributions

Linear transformation: given a random variable X∼\Norm(μ,σ2)X \sim \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X∼\Norm(μ,σ2),

(1.3)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼\Norm(aμ+b,a2σ2)\tag{1.3} \forall a, b \in \R, aX + b \sim \Norm(a\mu + b, a^2\sigma^2)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼\Norm(aμ+b,a2σ2)(1.3)

We can therefore standardize any normal distribution:

(1.4)Z=X−μσ∼\Norm(0,1)\tag{1.4} Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim \Norm(0, 1)Z=σX−μ​∼\Norm(0,1)(1.4)

We therefore have:

\P[u≤X≤v]=\P[u−μσ≤Z≤v−μσ]\P[u \leq X \leq v] = \P\left[\frac{u-\mu}{\sigma} \leq Z \leq \frac{v-\mu}{\sigma}\right]\P[u≤X≤v]=\P[σu−μ​≤Z≤σv−μ​]

The standard normal probability is also symmetric, which means:

\P[Z≥x]=\P[Z≤−x]\P[Z \geq x] = \P[Z \leq -x]\P[Z≥x]=\P[Z≤−x]

The quantile of order 1−α1-\alpha1−α of a random variable XXX is the number qαq_\alphaqα​ such as:

(1.5)\P[X≤qα]=1−α\tag{1.5} \P[X \leq q_\alpha] = 1 - \alpha\P[X≤qα​]=1−α(1.5)

Types of convergence

Let (Tn)n(T_n)_n(Tn​)n​ be a sequence of random variables, and TTT a random variable (which can be deterministic).

Convergence almost surely:

(1.6)Tn\convasT  ⟺  \P[{ω:Tn(ω)\convT(ω)}]=1\tag{1.6} T_n \convas T \iff \P\left[\left\{\omega: T_n(\omega) \conv{} T(\omega)\right\} \right] = 1Tn​\convasT⟺\P[{ω:Tn​(ω)\convT(ω)}]=1(1.6)

Convergence in probability:

(1.7)Tn\convpT  ⟺  ∀ε>0,\P[∣Tn−T∣≥ε]\conv0\tag{1.7} T_n \convp T \iff \forall \varepsilon > 0, \P[|T_n - T| \geq \varepsilon] \conv{} 0Tn​\convpT⟺∀ε>0,\P[∣Tn​−T∣≥ε]\conv0(1.7)

Convergence in distribution:

(1.8)Tn\convdT  ⟺  \E[f(Tn)]\conv\E[f(T)]\tag{1.8} T_n \convd T \iff \E[f(T_n)] \conv{} \E[f(T)]Tn​\convdT⟺\E[f(Tn​)]\conv\E[f(T)](1.8)

for all function fff continuous and bounded.

Convergence almost surely implies convergence in probability, which implies convergence in distribution.

If the limit has a density, then convergence in distribution implies convergence in probability.

Operations on convergence

Let (Tn)n,(Un)n(T_n)_n, (U_n)_n(Tn​)n​,(Un​)n​ but two sequences of random variables, and T,UT, UT,U be two random variables. If

Tn\conva.s./\PT,Un\conva.s/\PUT_n \conv{a.s./\P} T, U_n \conv{a.s/\P} UTn​\conva.s./\PT,Un​\conva.s/\PU

then:

(1.9)Tn+Un\conva.s/\PT+U\tag{1.9} T_n + U_n \conv{a.s/\P} T + UTn​+Un​\conva.s/\PT+U(1.9)
(1.10)TnUn\conva.s/\PTU\tag{1.10} T_nU_n \conv{a.s/\P} TUTn​Un​\conva.s/\PTU(1.10)

if in addition, U≠0U \neq 0U̸​=0 almost surely, then

(1.11)TnUn\conva.s/\PTU\tag{1.11} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \conv{a.s/\P} \frac{T}UUn​Tn​​\conva.s/\PUT​(1.11)

Slutsky's Theorem. Let u∈Ru \in \Ru∈R. If

Tn\convdT,Un\convpuT_n \convd T, U_n \convp uTn​\convdT,Un​\convpu

then:

(1.12)Tn+Un\convdT+u\tag{1.12} T_n + U_n \convd T + uTn​+Un​\convdT+u(1.12)
(1.13)TnUn\convduTn\tag{1.13} T_nU_n \convd uT_nTn​Un​\convduTn​(1.13)

if in addition, u≠0u \neq 0u̸​=0, then

(1.14)TnUn\convd1uT\tag{1.14} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \convd \frac1uTUn​Tn​​\convdu1​T(1.14)

Continuous mapping theorem. Let f∈C(R)f \in \mathcal{C}(\R)f∈C(R). If

Tn\conva.s./\P/(d)TT_n \conv{a.s./\P/(d)}TTn​\conva.s./\P/(d)T

then:

(1.15)f(Tn)\conva.s./\P/(d)f(T)\tag{1.15} f(T_n) \conv{a.s./\P/(d)} f(T)f(Tn​)\conva.s./\P/(d)f(T)(1.15)

Unit 2: Foundation of Inference

Lecture 3: Parametric Statistical Models

Trinity of statistical inference: estimation, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

Given X1,…,Xn\iid\PX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​\iid\P, the goal is to learn the distribution \P\P\P.

A statistical model is defined as:

(2.1)\statmodel\tag{2.1} \statmodel\statmodel(2.1)

where

  • EEE is the sample space,
  • (\Pθ)θ∈Θ(\P_\theta)_{\theta \in \Theta}(\Pθ​)θ∈Θ​ is a family of probability measures on EEE,
  • Θ\ThetaΘ is called the parameter set.

The model is well specified if

(2.2)∃θ∈Θ,\Pθ=\P\tag{2.2} \exists \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta = \P∃θ∈Θ,\Pθ​=\P(2.2)

The model is called:

  • parametric if Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd for some d∈Nd \in \Nd∈N,
  • non-parametric if Θ\ThetaΘ is infinite-dimensional,
  • semi-parametric if Θ=Θ1×Θ2\Theta = \Theta_1 \times \Theta_2Θ=Θ1​×Θ2​ where Θ1⊆Rd\Theta_1 \subseteq \R^dΘ1​⊆Rd is the parameter set we are interested in, and Θ2\Theta_2Θ2​ is the nuisance parameter set.

The parameter θ\thetaθ is called identifiable if the mapping θ↦\Pθ\theta \mapsto \P_\thetaθ↦\Pθ​ is injective, i.e.:

(2.3)∀θ1,θ2∈Θ,θ1≠θ2  ⟹  \Pθ1≠\Pθ2\tag{2.3} \forall \theta_1, \theta_2 \in \Theta, \theta_1 \neq \theta_2 \implies \P_{\theta_1} \neq \P_{\theta_2}∀θ1​,θ2​∈Θ,θ1​̸​=θ2​⟹\Pθ1​​̸​=\Pθ2​​(2.3)

Lecture 4: Parametric Estimation and Confidence Intervals

A statistic is any measurable function of the sample.

An estimator of θ\thetaθ is any statistic whose expression doesn't depend on θ\thetaθ.

An estimator \thn\thn\thn of θ\thetaθ is weakly (resp. strongly) consistent if:

(2.4)\thn\conv\P  (resp.  a.s.)θ(\Pθ)\tag{2.4} \thn \conv{\P\;(resp.\;a.s.)} \theta \quad (\P_\theta)\thn\conv\P(resp.a.s.)θ(\Pθ​)(2.4)

An estimator \thn\thn\thn of θ\thetaθ is asymptotically normal if:

(2.5)n(\thn−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)\tag{2.5} \sqrt{n}(\thn - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(\thn−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)(2.5)

The quantity σ2\sigma^2σ2 is called the asymptotic variance of \thn\thn\thn, noted

(2.6)V(\thn)=σ2\tag{2.6} V(\thn) = \sigma^2V(\thn)=σ2(2.6)

The bias of an estimator \thn\thn\thn of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(2.7)\Bias(\thn)=\E[\thn]−θ\tag{2.7} \Bias(\thn) = \E[\thn] - \theta\Bias(\thn)=\E[\thn]−θ(2.7)

If \Bias(\thn)=0\Bias(\thn) = 0\Bias(\thn)=0, then we say that \thn\thn\thn is unbiased.

The quadratic risk (or risk) of an estimator \thn\thn\thn is

(2.8)R(\thn)=\E[(\thn−θ)2]=\V[\thn]+\Bias(\thn)2\tag{2.8} R(\thn) = \E\left[(\thn - \theta)^2\right] = \V[\thn] + \Bias(\thn)^2R(\thn)=\E[(\thn−θ)2]=\V[\thn]+\Bias(\thn)2(2.8)

Let \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel be a statistical model with Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R associated with observations X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​, and α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1).

A confidence interval (C.I.) of level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval I\mathcal{I}I independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.9)∀θ∈Θ,\Pθ[I∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.9} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta[\mathcal{I} \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,\Pθ​[I∋θ]≥1−α(2.9)

A C.I. of asymptotic level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval In\mathcal{I}_nIn​ independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.10)∀θ∈Θ,\limn\Pθ[In∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.10} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \limn\P_\theta[\mathcal{I}_n \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,\limn\Pθ​[In​∋θ]≥1−α(2.10)

Example: X1,…,Xn\iid\Ber(p)X_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \Ber(p)X1​,…,Xn​\iid\Ber(p). Our estimator is \estp=Xˉn\est{p} = \bar{X}_n\estp=Xˉn​. From the CLT:

nXˉn−pp(1−p)\convd\Norm(0,1)\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}} \convd\Norm(0,1)n​p(1−p)​Xˉn​−p​\convd\Norm(0,1)

Therefore:

\P[np(1−p)∣Xˉn−p∣≤qα/2]=1−α\P\left[\frac{\sqrt{n}}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}}|\bar{X}_n - p| \leq q_{\alpha/2}\right] = 1-\alpha \P[p(1−p)​n​​∣Xˉn​−p∣≤qα/2​]=1−α
\P[[Xˉn−p(1−p)nqα/2,Xˉn+p(1−p)nqα/2]∋p]=1−α\P\left[\left[\bar{X}_n - \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}, \bar{X}_n + \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}\right] \ni p\right] = 1-\alpha\P[[Xˉn​−np(1−p)​​qα/2​,Xˉn​+np(1−p)​​qα/2​]∋p]=1−α

But this is not an asymptotic C.I. because the interval depends on ppp. We have three ways to find an actual confidence inteval:

Convervative bounds:

∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤14  ⟹  Iconv=Xˉn+[−qα/22n,qα/22n]\forall p \in (0, 1), p(1-p) \leq \frac14 \implies \mathcal{I}_{conv} = \bar{X}_n + \left[-\frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}, \frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}\right]∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤41​⟹Iconv​=Xˉn​+[−2n​qα/2​​,2n​qα/2​​]

Solve bounds, by solving the quadratic equation in ppp:

(p−Xˉn)2≤qα/22np(1−p)  ⟹  Isolve=[p1,p2](p - \bar{X}_n)^2 \leq \frac{q^2_{\alpha/2}}{n}p(1-p) \implies \mathcal{I}_{solve} = [p_1, p_2](p−Xˉn​)2≤nqα/22​​p(1−p)⟹Isolve​=[p1​,p2​]

Plug-in bounds; as \estp\convasp\est{p} \convas p\estp\convasp, we can apply Slutsky's theorem:

nXˉn−p\estp(1−\estp)\convd\Norm(0,1)  ⟹  Iplug=Xˉn+qα/2[−\estp(1−\estp)n,\estp(1−\estp)n]\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n-p}{\sqrt{\est{p}(1 -\est{p})}} \convd \Norm(0, 1) \implies \mathcal{I}_{plug} = \bar{X}_n + q_{\alpha/2}\left[-\sqrt{\frac{\est{p}(1-\est{p})}{n}}, \sqrt{\frac{\est{p}(1-\est{p})}{n}}\right]n​\estp(1−\estp)​Xˉn​−p​\convd\Norm(0,1)⟹Iplug​=Xˉn​+qα/2​[−n\estp(1−\estp)​​,n\estp(1−\estp)​​]

All three intervals verify:

\limn\P[I∋p]≥1−α\limn \P[\mathcal{I} \ni p] \geq 1 - \alpha\limn\P[I∋p]≥1−α

If I\mathcal{I}I is a confidence interval of level α\alphaα, it is also a confidence interval of level β\betaβ for all β≤α\beta \leq \alphaβ≤α.

A confidence interval of level α\alphaα means that if we repeat the experience multiple times, then the real parameter will be in the confidence interval with frequency α\alphaα. It does not mean that the real parameter is in the interval with a certain confidence (as the real parameter is deterministic).

Lecture 5: Delta Method and Confidence Intervals

The Delta Method. Let (Xn)n(X_n)_n(Xn​)n​ be a sequence of r.v. such as

n(Xn−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(X_n - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xn​−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)

for some θ∈R,σ2>0\theta \in \R, \sigma^2 > 0θ∈R,σ2>0. Let g:R→Rg: \R \rightarrow \Rg:R→R continuously differentiable at θ\thetaθ. Then (g(Xn))n(g(X_n))_n(g(Xn​))n​ is asymptotically normal around g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ) and:

(2.11)n(g(Xn)−g(θ))\convd\Norm(0,g′(θ)2σ2)\tag{2.11}\sqrt{n}(g(X_n) - g(\theta)) \convd \Norm(0, g'(\theta)^2\sigma^2)n​(g(Xn​)−g(θ))\convd\Norm(0,g′(θ)2σ2)(2.11)

Lecture 6: Introduction to Hypothesis Testing, and Type 1 and Type 2 Errors

Let us consider a sample X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ of i.i.d r.v. and a statistical model \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel. Let us consider Θ0⨿Θ1=Θ\Theta_0 \amalg \Theta_1 = \ThetaΘ0​⨿Θ1​=Θ.

  • H0:θ∈Θ0H_0: \theta \in \Theta_0H0​:θ∈Θ0​ is called the null hypothesis,
  • H1:θ∈Θ1H_1: \theta \in \Theta_1H1​:θ∈Θ1​ is called the alternative hypothesis.

We are testing H0H_0H0​ against H1H_1H1​ to decide whether to reject H0H_0H0​ by looking for evidence against H0H_0H0​.

H0H_0H0​ and H1H_1H1​ do not play symmetric roles in hypothesis testing: H0H_0H0​ is the default hypothesis when we lack evidence.

A test is a statistic ψ:En→{0,1}\psi : E^n \rightarrow \{0, 1\}ψ:En→{0,1} such as:

  • If ψ(x1,…,xn)=0\psi(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 0ψ(x1​,…,xn​)=0 then H0H_0H0​ is not rejected,
  • If ψ(x1,…,xn)=1\psi(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 1ψ(x1​,…,xn​)=1 then H0H_0H0​ is rejected and H1H_1H1​ is accepted.

The rejection region of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.12)Rψ={\xx∈En,ψ(\xx)=1}\tag{2.12} R_\psi = \{\xx \in E^n, \psi(\xx) = 1\}Rψ​={\xx∈En,ψ(\xx)=1}(2.12)

The type 1 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to rejecting H0H_0H0​ when it is actually true:

(2.13)\funαψΘ0[0,1]θ\Pθ[ψ(\XX)=1]\tag{2.13} \fun{\alpha_\psi}{\Theta_0}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 1]}\funαψ​Θ0​[0,1]θ\Pθ​[ψ(\XX)=1](2.13)

The type 2 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to not rejecting H0H_0H0​ when H1H_1H1​ is actually true:

(2.14)\funβψΘ1[0,1]θ\Pθ[ψ(\XX)=0]\tag{2.14} \fun{\beta_\psi}{\Theta_1}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 0]}\funβψ​Θ1​[0,1]θ\Pθ​[ψ(\XX)=0](2.14)

Type 1 and type 2 errors are summaries as follows (RRR is real, TTT is test):

R\TH0H1H0✓1H12✓\begin{array}{ccc}R\char`\\ T & H_0 & H_1 \\ H_0 & \checkmark & 1 \\ H_1 & 2 & \checkmark \end{array}R\TH0​H1​​H0​✓2​H1​1✓​

The power of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.15)πψ=inf⁡θ∈Θ1(1−βψ(θ))\tag{2.15} \pi_\psi = \inf_{\theta \in \Theta_1}(1 - \beta_\psi(\theta))πψ​=θ∈Θ1​inf​(1−βψ​(θ))(2.15)

Lecture 7: Hypothesis Testing (Continued): Levels and P-values

A test ψ\psiψ has level α\alphaα if:

(2.16)∀θ∈Θ0,αψ(θ)≤α\tag{2.16} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \alpha_\psi(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,αψ​(θ)≤α(2.16)

A test ψ\psiψ has asymptotic level α\alphaα if:

(2.17)∀θ∈Θ0,\limnαψn(θ)≤α\tag{2.17} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \limn \alpha_{\psi_n}(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,\limnαψn​​(θ)≤α(2.17)

In general, a test has the form

ψ=\one{Tn>c}\psi = \one\{T_n > c\}ψ=\one{Tn​>c}

for some statistic TnT_nTn​ and threshold ccc. TnT_nTn​ is called the test statistic and the rejection region is Rψ={Tn>c}R_\psi = \{T_n > c\}Rψ​={Tn​>c}.

We have two main types of tests:

  • If H0:θ=θ0H_0: \theta = \theta_0H0​:θ=θ0​ and H1:θ≠θ0H_1: \theta \neq \theta_0H1​:θ̸​=θ0​, it is a two-sided test,
  • If H0:θ≤θ0H_0: \theta \leq \theta_0H0​:θ≤θ0​ and H1:θ>θ0H_1: \theta > \theta_0H1​:θ>θ0​, it is a one-sided test.

Example: Let X1,…,Xn\iidD(μ)X_1, …, X_n \iid \mathcal{D}(\mu)X1​,…,Xn​\iidD(μ) where μ\muμ and σ2\sigma^2σ2 are the expectation and variance of D(μ)\mathcal{D}(\mu)D(μ). Let's consider μ0\mu_0μ0​.

We want to test H0:μ=μ0H_0: \mu = \mu_0H0​:μ=μ0​ against H1:μ≠μ0H_1: \mu \neq \mu_0H1​:μ̸​=μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα.

(2.18)Tn=n\estμ−μ0σ\convd\Norm(0,1)\tag{2.18} T_n = \sqrt{n}\frac{\est{\mu} - \mu_0}{\sigma} \convd \Norm(0, 1)Tn​=n​σ\estμ−μ0​​\convd\Norm(0,1)(2.18)

Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

\P[∣Tn∣>qα/2]\convα\P[|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}] \conv{} \alpha\P[∣Tn​∣>qα/2​]\convα

Let ψα=\one{∣Tn∣>qα/2}\psi_\alpha = \one\{|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}\}ψα​=\one{∣Tn​∣>qα/2​}.

Now, we want to test H0:μ≤μ0H_0: \mu \leq \mu_0H0​:μ≤μ0​ and H1:μ>μ0H_1: \mu > \mu_0H1​:μ>μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα. Which value of μ∈Θ0\mu \in \Theta_0μ∈Θ0​ should we consider?

Type 1 error is the function μ↦\Pμ[ψ(\XX)=1]\mu \mapsto \P_\mu[\psi(\XX) = 1]μ↦\Pμ​[ψ(\XX)=1]. To control the level, we need the μ\muμ that maximises this expression over Θ0\Theta_0Θ0​: clearly, this happens for μ=μ0\mu = \mu_0μ=μ0​. Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

\Pμ0[Tn>qα]\convα\P_{\mu_0}[T_n > q_\alpha] \conv{} \alpha\Pμ0​​[Tn​>qα​]\convα

If H1:μ<μ0H_1: \mu < \mu_0H1​:μ<μ0​, then we want \Pμ0[Tn<−qα]\P_{\mu_0}[T_n < -q_\alpha]\Pμ0​​[Tn​<−qα​].

The (asymptotic) p-value of a test ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ is the smallest (asymptotic) level α\alphaα at which ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ rejects H0H_0H0​. The p-value is random and depends on the sample.

The golden rule: H0H_0H0​ is rejected by ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ at any asymptotic level α≥\pval(\XX)\alpha \geq \pval(\XX)α≥\pval(\XX).

Unit 3: Methods of estimation

Lecture 8: Distance measures between distributions

Let \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel a statistical model, associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​. We assume the model is well specified, i.e. ∃\tth∈Θ,X∼\P\tth\exists \tth \in \Theta, X \sim \P_\tth∃\tth∈Θ,X∼\P\tth​. \tth\tth\tth is called the true parameter.

We want to find an estimator \thn\thn\thn such that \P\thn\P_{\thn}\P\thn​ is close to \P\tth\P_\tth\P\tth​.

The total variation distance between two probability measures \P1\P_1\P1​ and \P2\P_2\P2​ is defined as:

(3.1)\TV(\P1,\P2)=max⁡A⊂E∣\P1(A)−\P2(A)∣\tag{3.1} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \max_{A \subset E}|\P_1(A) - \P_2(A)|\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=A⊂Emax​∣\P1​(A)−\P2​(A)∣(3.1)

If EEE is discrete, and p1,p2p_1, p_2p1​,p2​ are the PMF associated with \P1\P_1\P1​ and \P2\P_2\P2​:

(3.2)\TV(\P1,\P2)=12∑x∈E∣p1(x)−p2(x)∣\tag{3.2} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\sum_{x\in E}|p_1(x) - p_2(x)|\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=21​x∈E∑​∣p1​(x)−p2​(x)∣(3.2)

If EEE is continuous, and f1,f2f_1, f_2f1​,f2​ are the PDF associated with \P1\P_1\P1​ and \P2\P_2\P2​:

(3.3)\TV(\P1,\P2)=12∫E∣f1(x)−f2(x)∣dx\tag{3.3} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\int_E|f_1(x) - f_2(x)|dx\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=21​∫E​∣f1​(x)−f2​(x)∣dx(3.3)

Proprieties of the total variation distance:

  • The \TV\TV\TV is symmetric: ∀\P1,\P2,\TV(\P1,\P2)=\TV(\P2,\P1)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \TV(\P_2, \P_1)∀\P1​,\P2​,\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=\TV(\P2​,\P1​)
  • The \TV\TV\TV is positive: ∀\P1,\P2,0≤\TV(\P1,\P2)≤1\forall \P_1, \P_2, 0 \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) \leq 1∀\P1​,\P2​,0≤\TV(\P1​,\P2​)≤1
  • The \TV\TV\TV is definite: ∀\P1,\P2,\TV(\P1,\P2)=0  ⟹  \P1=\P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀\P1​,\P2​,\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=0⟹\P1​=\P2​ p.p.
  • The \TV\TV\TV verifies the triangle inequality: ∀\P1,\P2,\P3,\TV(\P1,\P3)≤\TV(\P1,\P2)+\TV(\P2,\P3)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \P_3, \TV(\P_1, \P_3) \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) + \TV(\P_2, \P_3)∀\P1​,\P2​,\P3​,\TV(\P1​,\P3​)≤\TV(\P1​,\P2​)+\TV(\P2​,\P3​)

Therefore, \TV\TV\TV is a distance between probability distributions.

Problem 1: \TV\TV\TV cannot compare discrete and continuous distributions, which means we cannot trust it to give a reliable estimation of distance between unrelated distributions.

Problem 2: We cannot build an estimator θ↦\TV^(\Pθ,\P\tth)\theta \mapsto \widehat{\TV}(\P_\theta, \P_\tth)θ↦\TV​(\Pθ​,\P\tth​) as we do not know \tth\tth\tth.

Hence we need another "distance" between distributions. The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between two probability distributions \P1,\P2\P_1, \P_2\P1​,\P2​ is defined as:

(3.4)\KL(\P1,\P2)={∑x∈Ep1(x)ln⁡p1(x)p2(x)if E is discrete∫Ef1(x)ln⁡f1(x)f2(x)dxif E is continuous\tag{3.4} \KL(\P_1, \P_2)= \begin{cases}\displaystyle\sum_{x\in E}p_1(x)\ln\frac{p_1(x)}{p_2(x)} & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \int_Ef_1(x)\ln\frac{f_1(x)}{f_2(x)}dx & \text{if }E\text{ is continuous}\end{cases}\KL(\P1​,\P2​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​x∈E∑​p1​(x)lnp2​(x)p1​(x)​∫E​f1​(x)lnf2​(x)f1​(x)​dx​if E is discreteif E is continuous​(3.4)

Proprieties of the \KL\KL\KL divergence:

  • In general, \KL(\P1,\P2)≠\KL(\P2,\P1)\KL(\P_1, \P_2) \neq \KL(\P_2, \P_1)\KL(\P1​,\P2​)̸​=\KL(\P2​,\P1​)
  • The \KL\KL\KL is positive: ∀\P1,\P2,\KL(\P1,\P2)≥0\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) \geq 0∀\P1​,\P2​,\KL(\P1​,\P2​)≥0
  • The \KL\KL\KL is definite: ∀\P1,\P2,\KL(\P1,\P2)=0  ⟹  \P1=\P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀\P1​,\P2​,\KL(\P1​,\P2​)=0⟹\P1​=\P2​
  • In general, \KL(\P1,\P3)̸≤\KL(\P1,\P2)+\KL(\P2,\P3)\KL(\P_1, \P_3) \not\leq \KL(\P_1, \P_2) + \KL(\P_2, \P_3)\KL(\P1​,\P3​)̸​≤\KL(\P1​,\P2​)+\KL(\P2​,\P3​)

\KL\KL\KL is not a distance, it's a divergence. But we still have that \tth\tth\tth is the only minimizer of θ↦\KL(\P\tth,\Pθ)\theta \mapsto \KL(\P_\tth, \P_\theta)θ↦\KL(\P\tth​,\Pθ​).

Lecture 9: Maximum Likelihood Estimation

\KL(\P\tth,\Pθ)=\E\tth[ln⁡f\tth(X)fθ(X)]=\E\tth[ln⁡f\tth(X)]−\E\tth[ln⁡fθ(X)]\begin{aligned}\KL(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) &= \E_\tth\left[\ln\frac{f_\tth(X)}{f_\theta(X)}\right] \\ &= \E_\tth[\ln f_\tth(X)] - \E_\tth[\ln f_\theta(X)]\end{aligned}\KL(\P\tth​,\Pθ​)​=\E\tth​[lnfθ​(X)f\tth​(X)​]=\E\tth​[lnf\tth​(X)]−\E\tth​[lnfθ​(X)]​

Therefore, by the LLN the \KL\KL\KL divergence can be estimated by taking the average of ln⁡fθ(Xi)\ln f_\theta(X_i)lnfθ​(Xi​):

\KL^(\P\tth,\Pθ)=constant−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)\widehat{\KL}(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) = \text{constant} - \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i)\KL​(\P\tth​,\Pθ​)=constant−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)

Therefore:

\argminθ∈Θ\KL^(\P\tth,\Pθ)=\argminθ∈Θ−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)=\argmaxθ∈Θln⁡∏i=1nfθ(Xi)=\argmaxθ∈Θ∏i=1nfθ(Xi)\begin{aligned} \argmin{\theta \in \Theta}\widehat{\KL}(\P_\tth, \P_\theta) &= \argmin{\theta \in \Theta} -\frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\ln\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \end{aligned}\argminθ∈Θ\KL​(\P\tth​,\Pθ​)​=\argminθ∈Θ−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)=\argmaxθ∈Θlni=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)=\argmaxθ∈Θi=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)​

This is the maximum likelihood principle.

Let \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel be a statistical model associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​. The likelihood of the model is the function:

(3.5)\funLnEn×Θ[0,1](x1,…,xn,θ){∏i=1npθ(xi)if E is discrete∏i=1nfθ(xi)if E is continous\tag{3.5}\fun{L_n}{E^n \times \Theta}{[0, 1]}{(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta)}{\begin{cases} \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^np_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is continous} \end{cases}}\funLn​En×Θ[0,1](x1​,…,xn​,θ)⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​i=1∏n​pθ​(xi​)i=1∏n​fθ​(xi​)​if E is discreteif E is continous​(3.5)

The maximum likelihood estimator of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(3.6)\thnMLE=\argmaxθ∈ΘLn(X1,…,Xn,θ)\tag{3.6} \thn^{MLE} = \argmax{\theta \in \Theta} L_n(X_1, \ldots, X_n, \theta)\thnMLE=\argmaxθ∈ΘLn​(X1​,…,Xn​,θ)(3.6)

In practice, we often use the log-likelihood ℓn(x1,…,xn,θ)=ln⁡Ln(x1,…,xn,θ)\ell_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta) = \ln L_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \theta)ℓn​(x1​,…,xn​,θ)=lnLn​(x1​,…,xn​,θ).

A function twice differentiable h:Θ⊆R→Rh : \Theta \subseteq \R \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆R→R is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.7)∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.7} \forall \theta \in \Theta, h''(\theta) \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)(3.7)

hhh is convex (resp. strictly) if −h-h−h is concave (resp. strictly).

A con-v-ex function is shaped like a v.

Let h:Θ⊆Rd→Rh: \Theta \subseteq \R^d \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆Rd→R be a multivariate function. The gradient vector of hhh is:

(3.8)∇h(\ttheta)=(\diffhθ1(\ttheta)⋮\diffhθd(\ttheta))\tag{3.8} \nabla h(\ttheta) = \begin{pmatrix}\displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_1}(\ttheta) \\ \displaystyle \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_d}(\ttheta)\end{pmatrix}∇h(\ttheta)=⎝⎜⎛​\diffhθ1​(\ttheta)⋮\diffhθd​(\ttheta)​⎠⎟⎞​(3.8)

The Hessian matrix of hhh is:

(3.9)\HHh(\ttheta)=(\diffkhθ12(\ttheta)⋯\diffdhθ1θd(\ttheta)⋮⋱⋮\diffdhθdθ1(\ttheta)⋯\diffkhθd2(\ttheta))∈Rd×d\tag{3.9} \HH h(\ttheta) = \begin{pmatrix} \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_1}{2}(\ttheta) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_1}{\theta_d}(\ttheta) \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_d}{\theta_1}(\ttheta) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_d}{2}(\ttheta) \\ \end{pmatrix} \in \R^{d\times d}\HHh(\ttheta)=⎝⎜⎛​\diffkhθ1​2(\ttheta)⋮\diffdhθd​θ1​(\ttheta)​⋯⋱⋯​\diffdhθ1​θd​(\ttheta)⋮\diffkhθd​2(\ttheta)​⎠⎟⎞​∈Rd×d(3.9)

Therefore, hhh is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.10)∀\xx∈Rd∖{\zz},\ttheta∈Θ,\xxT\HHh(\ttheta)\xx≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.10} \forall \xx \in \R^d \setminus \{\zz\}, \ttheta \in \Theta, \xx^T\HH h(\ttheta)\xx \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀\xx∈Rd∖{\zz},\ttheta∈Θ,\xxT\HHh(\ttheta)\xx≤0(resp. <0)(3.10)

If hhh is strictly concave and has a maximum, then this maximum is unique and is reached for

(3.11){h′(θ)=0if Θ⊆R∇h(\ttheta)=\zzif Θ⊆Rd\tag{3.11} \begin{cases} h'(\theta) = 0 & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R \\ \nabla h(\ttheta) = \zz & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R^d \end{cases}{h′(θ)=0∇h(\ttheta)=\zz​if Θ⊆Rif Θ⊆Rd​(3.11)

Lecture 10: Consistency of MLE, Covariance Matrices, and Multivariate Statistics

Under mild regularity conditions, we have

(3.12)\thnMLE\convp\tth\tag{3.12} \thn^{MLE} \convp \tth\thnMLE\convp\tth(3.12)

Notably if the model is well specified.

In general, when θ∈Rd\theta \in \R^dθ∈Rd, the coordinates are not independent. The covariance between two random variables XXX and YYY is defined as:

(3.13)\Cov(X,Y)=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]\tag{3.13} \begin{aligned} \Cov(X, Y) &= \E[(X - \E[X])(Y - \E[Y])] \\ &= \E[XY] - \E[X]\E[Y] \\ &= \E[X(Y - \E[Y])] \end{aligned}\Cov(X,Y)​=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]​(3.13)

Properties:

(3.14)\Cov(X,X)=\V(X)\tag{3.14} \Cov(X, X) = \V(X)\Cov(X,X)=\V(X)(3.14)
(3.15)\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)\tag{3.15} \Cov(X, Y) = \Cov(Y, X)\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)(3.15)

If XXX and YYY are independent, then \Cov(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0\Cov(X,Y)=0 and \E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y]\E[XY] = \E[X]\E[Y]\E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y].

Attention: the converse is not true; if \Cov(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0\Cov(X,Y)=0, XXX and YYY may be dependent.

If \XX=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd\XX = (X^{(1)}, \ldots, X^{(d)})^T \in \R^d\XX=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd, then the covariance matrix of the vector is given by:

(3.16)\SSigma=\CCov(\XX)=\E[(\XX−\E[\XX])(\XX−\E[\XX])T]∈Rd×d\tag{3.16} \SSigma = \CCov(\XX) = \E[(\XX - \E[\XX])(\XX - \E[\XX])^T] \in \R^{d \times d}\SSigma=\CCov(\XX)=\E[(\XX−\E[\XX])(\XX−\E[\XX])T]∈Rd×d(3.16)

Its terms are:

\SSigmai,j=\Cov(X(i),X(j))\SSigma_{i,j} = \Cov(X^{(i)}, X^{(j)})\SSigmai,j​=\Cov(X(i),X(j))

Proprieties:

(3.17)\CCov(A\XX+B)=\CCov(A\XX)=A\CCov(\XX)AT\tag{3.17} \CCov(A\XX + B) = \CCov(A\XX) = A\CCov(\XX)A^T\CCov(A\XX+B)=\CCov(A\XX)=A\CCov(\XX)AT(3.17)

The Multivariate Central Limit Theorem, let \XX1,…,\XXn∈Rd\XX_1, \ldots, \XX_n \in \R^d\XX1​,…,\XXn​∈Rd i.i.d copies of \XX\XX\XX such that \E[\XX]=\mmu\E[\XX] = \mmu\E[\XX]=\mmu and \CCov(\XX)=\SSigma\CCov(\XX) = \SSigma\CCov(\XX)=\SSigma. Then:

(3.18)n(\XXˉn−\mmu)\convd\Normd(\zz,\SSigma)\tag{3.18} \sqrt{n}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(\XXˉ​n​−\mmu)\convd\Normd​(\zz,\SSigma)(3.18)

Equivalently,

n\SSigma−1/2(\XXˉn−\mmu)\convd\Normd(\zz,Id)\sqrt{n}\SSigma^{-1/2}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, I_d)n​\SSigma−1/2(\XXˉ​n​−\mmu)\convd\Normd​(\zz,Id​)

The Multivariate Delta Method, let (\TTn)n∈(Rd)N(\TT_n)_n \in (\R^d)^\N(\TTn​)n​∈(Rd)N be a sequence of random vectors such that

n(\TTn−\ttheta)\convd\Normd(\zz,\SSigma)\sqrt{n}(\TT_n - \ttheta) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(\TTn​−\ttheta)\convd\Normd​(\zz,\SSigma)

with \ttheta∈Rd,\SSigma∈Rd×d\ttheta \in \R^d, \SSigma \in \R^{d\times d}\ttheta∈Rd,\SSigma∈Rd×d. Let g:Rd→Rk\bm{g}: \R^d \rightarrow \R^kg:Rd→Rk be continuously differentiable in \ttheta\ttheta\ttheta. Then:

(3.19)n(g(\TTn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk(\zz,∇g(\ttheta)T\SSigma∇g(\ttheta))\tag{3.19} \sqrt{n}(\bm{g}(\TT_n) - \bm{g}(\ttheta)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, \nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta)^T\SSigma\nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta))n​(g(\TTn​)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk​(\zz,∇g(\ttheta)T\SSigma∇g(\ttheta))(3.19)

where

∇g(\ttheta)=(\diffgjθi)i,j=(∇g1(\ttheta),⋯ ,∇gk(\ttheta))\nabla \bm{g}(\ttheta) = \left(\diff{g_j}{\theta_i}\right)_{i, j} = \left(\nabla g_1(\ttheta), \cdots,\nabla g_k(\ttheta)\right)∇g(\ttheta)=(\diffgj​θi​)i,j​=(∇g1​(\ttheta),⋯,∇gk​(\ttheta))

Lecture 11: Fisher Information, Asymptotic Normality of MLE; Methods of Moments

Let \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel be a statistical model with Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd, and \XX\XX\XX an associated random variable. With

ℓ(\ttheta)=ln⁡L1(\XX,\ttheta)\ell(\ttheta) = \ln L_1(\XX, \ttheta)ℓ(\ttheta)=lnL1​(\XX,\ttheta)

The Fisher Information of the model is defined as:

(3.20)I:\ttheta↦\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)∇ℓ(\ttheta)T]−\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)]\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)]T\tag{3.20} I : \ttheta \mapsto \E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)\nabla\ell(\ttheta)^T] - \E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)]\E[\nabla\ell(\ttheta)]^TI:\ttheta↦\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)∇ℓ(\ttheta)T]−\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)]\E[∇ℓ(\ttheta)]T(3.20)

Under some regularity conditions, we have that:

(3.21)I(\ttheta)=−\E[\HHℓ(\ttheta)]\tag{3.21} I(\ttheta) = - \E[\HH\ell(\ttheta)]I(\ttheta)=−\E[\HHℓ(\ttheta)](3.21)

If Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R, we have:

(3.22)I(θ)=\V[ℓ′(θ)]=−\E[ℓ′′(θ)]\tag{3.22} I(\theta) = \V[\ell'(\theta)] = -\E[\ell''(\theta)]I(θ)=\V[ℓ′(θ)]=−\E[ℓ′′(θ)](3.22)

Asymptotic normality of the MLE. Let \ttth∈Θ\ttth \in \Theta\ttth∈Θ be the true parameter. If we have the following:

  • \ttth\ttth\ttth is identifiable,
  • ∀\ttheta∈Θ\forall \ttheta \in \Theta∀\ttheta∈Θ, the support of \Pθ\P_\theta\Pθ​ does not depend on θ\thetaθ,
  • \ttth\ttth\ttth is not on the boundary of Θ\ThetaΘ,
  • I(\ttheta)I(\ttheta)I(\ttheta) is invertible in a neighborhood of \ttth\ttth\ttth,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then \tthnMLE\tthn^{MLE}\tthnMLE satisfies:

(3.23)\tthnMLE\convp\ttth[\P\ttth]\tag{3.23} \tthn^{MLE} \convp \ttth \quad [\P_{\ttth}]\tthnMLE\convp\ttth[\P\ttth​](3.23)
(3.24)n(\tthnMLE−\ttth)\convd\Normd(0,I(\ttth)−1)[\P\ttth]\tag{3.24} \sqrt{n}(\tthn^{MLE} - \ttth) \convd \Norm_d(0, I(\ttth)^{-1}) \quad [\P_{\ttth}]n​(\tthnMLE−\ttth)\convd\Normd​(0,I(\ttth)−1)[\P\ttth​](3.24)

Let \XX1,…,\XXn\XX_1, …, \XX_n\XX1​,…,\XXn​ be an i.i.d sample associated with a statistical model \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel, with E⊆RE \subseteq \RE⊆R and Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd. The population moments are:

(3.25)∀1≤k≤d,mk(\ttheta)=\E\ttheta[Xk]\tag{3.25} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, m_k(\ttheta) = \E_\ttheta[X^k]∀1≤k≤d,mk​(\ttheta)=\E\ttheta​[Xk](3.25)

And the empirical moments are:

(3.26)∀1≤k≤d,m^k=Xnk‾=1n∑i=1nXik\tag{3.26} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, \hat{m}_k = \overline{X^k_n} = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^nX_i^k∀1≤k≤d,m^k​=Xnk​​=n1​i=1∑n​Xik​(3.26)

From the LLN, we have

(3.27)(m^1,…,m^d)\conv\P/a.s.(m1(\ttheta),…,md(\ttheta))\tag{3.27} (\hat{m}_1, \ldots, \hat{m}_d) \conv{\P / a.s.} (m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, m_d(\ttheta))(m^1​,…,m^d​)\conv\P/a.s.(m1​(\ttheta),…,md​(\ttheta))(3.27)

Let

\funMΘRd\tthetaM(\ttheta)=(m1(\ttheta),…,nd(\ttheta))\fun{M}{\Theta}{\R^d}{\ttheta}{M(\ttheta) = (m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, n_d(\ttheta))}\funMΘRd\tthetaM(\ttheta)=(m1​(\ttheta),…,nd​(\ttheta))

Then if MMM is injective, \ttheta=M−1(m1(\ttheta),…,md(\ttheta))\ttheta = M^{-1}(m_1(\ttheta), \ldots, m_d(\ttheta))\ttheta=M−1(m1​(\ttheta),…,md​(\ttheta))

The moment estimator of \ttheta\ttheta\ttheta, if it exists, is defined as

(3.28)\tthnMM=M−1(m^1,…,m^d)\tag{3.28} \tthn^{MM} = M^{-1}(\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)\tthnMM=M−1(m^1​,…,m^d​)(3.28)

Let M^=(m^1,…,m^d)\hat M = (\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)M^=(m^1​,…,m^d​). Let \SSigma(\ttheta)=\CCov\ttheta(X,X2,…,Xd)\SSigma(\ttheta) = \CCov_\ttheta(X, X^2, \ldots, X^d)\SSigma(\ttheta)=\CCov\ttheta​(X,X2,…,Xd). Let us assume M−1M^{-1}M−1 is continuously differentiable at M(\ttheta)M(\ttheta)M(\ttheta).

We can generalize the method of moments to any set of functions g1,…,gd:R→Rg_1, \ldots, g_d : R \rightarrow \Rg1​,…,gd​:R→R well chosen, by defining mk(\ttheta)=\E\ttheta[gk(X)]m_k(\ttheta) = \E_\ttheta[g_k(X)]mk​(\ttheta)=\E\ttheta​[gk​(X)] and \SSigma(\ttheta)=\CCov\ttheta(g1(X),…,gk(X))\SSigma(\ttheta) = \CCov_\ttheta(g_1(X), \ldots, g_k(X))\SSigma(\ttheta)=\CCov\ttheta​(g1​(X),…,gk​(X)).

The generalized method of moments yields, by applying the CLT and the Delta method:

(3.29)n(\tthnMM−θ)\convd\Normd(\zz,Γ(\ttheta))\tag{3.29} \sqrt{n}(\tthn^{MM} - \theta) \convd\Norm_d(\zz, \Gamma(\ttheta))n​(\tthnMM−θ)\convd\Normd​(\zz,Γ(\ttheta))(3.29)

where

Γ(\ttheta)=[∇M−1(M(\ttheta))]T\SSigma(\ttheta)[∇M−1(M(\ttheta))]\Gamma(\ttheta) = \left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\ttheta))\right]^T\SSigma(\ttheta)\left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\ttheta))\right]Γ(\ttheta)=[∇M−1(M(\ttheta))]T\SSigma(\ttheta)[∇M−1(M(\ttheta))]

The MLEMLEMLE is more accurate than the MMMMMM, the MLEMLEMLE still gives good results if the model is mis-specified, however the MMMMMM is easier to compute and the MLEMLEMLE can be intractable sometimes.

Lecture 12: M-Estimation

Let X1,…,Xn\iid\PX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​\iid\P on a sample space E⊆RdE \subseteq \R^dE⊆Rd.

The goal is to estimate some parameter \true\mmu\true\mmu\true\mmu associated with \P\P\P. We find a function ρ:E×M→R\rho : E \times \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \Rρ:E×M→R, where M\mathcal{M}M is the parameter set for \true\mmu\true\mmu\true\mmu, such that:

Q(\mmu)=\E[ρ(\XX,\mmu)]\mathcal{Q}(\mmu) = \E[\rho(\XX, \mmu)]Q(\mmu)=\E[ρ(\XX,\mmu)]

verifies

(3.30)\trueμ=\argminμ∈MQ(μ)\tag{3.30} \true\mu = \argmin{\mu \in \mathcal{M}}\mathcal{Q}(\mu)\trueμ=\argminμ∈MQ(μ)(3.30)

For example:

  • if ρ(\xx,\mmu)=∥\xx−\mmu∥22\rho(\xx, \mmu) = \|\xx - \mmu\|_2^2ρ(\xx,\mmu)=∥\xx−\mmu∥22​, then \true\mmu=\E[\XX]\true\mmu = \E[\XX]\true\mmu=\E[\XX].
  • if ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣\rho(x, \mu) = |x - \mu|ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣, then \trueμ=\Med(X)\true\mu = \Med{}(X)\trueμ=\Med(X).

Let α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1). We define the check functions:

\funCαRRx{−(1−α)xif x<0αxif x≥0\fun{C_\alpha}{\R}{\R}{x}{\begin{cases} -(1-\alpha)x & \text{if } x < 0 \\ \alpha x & \text{if } x \geq 0 \end{cases}}\funCα​RRx{−(1−α)xαx​if x<0if x≥0​

If \statmodel\statmodel\statmodel is a statistical model associated with the data, M=Θ\mathcal{M} = \ThetaM=Θ, and ρ=−ℓ1\rho = -\ell_1ρ=−ℓ1​ the negative log-likelihood, then

(3.31)\true\mmu=\ttth\tag{3.31}\true\mmu = \ttth\true\mmu=\ttth(3.31)

where \P=\P\ttth\P = \P_\ttth\P=\P\ttth​. As such, the MLEMLEMLE estimator is an M-estimator.

Let

J(\mmu)=\HHQ(\mmu)J(\mmu) = \HH Q(\mmu)J(\mmu)=\HHQ(\mmu)

under some regularity conditions,

J(\mmu)=\E[\diffdρ\mmu\mmuT(X,\mmu)]J(\mmu) = \E\left[\diffd{\rho}{\mmu}{\mmu^T}(X, \mmu)\right]J(\mmu)=\E[\diffdρ\mmu\mmuT(X,\mmu)]

Let

K(\mmu)=\CCov[∇\mmuρ(X,\mmu)]K(\mmu) = \CCov\left[\nabla_\mmu\rho(X, \mmu)\right]K(\mmu)=\CCov[∇\mmu​ρ(X,\mmu)]

In the case of the log-likelihood, we have J(\ttheta)=K(\ttheta)=I(\ttheta)J(\ttheta) = K(\ttheta) = I(\ttheta)J(\ttheta)=K(\ttheta)=I(\ttheta).

Let \true\mmu∈M\true\mmu \in \mathcal{M}\true\mmu∈M be the true parameter. If we have:

  • \true\mmu\true\mmu\true\mmu is the only minimizer of Q\mathcal{Q}Q,
  • J(\mmu)J(\mmu)J(\mmu) is invertible for all \mmu∈M\mmu \in \mathcal{M}\mmu∈M,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then \est\mmu\est{\mmu}\est\mmu satisfies:

(3.32)\est\mmu\convp\true\mmu\tag{3.32} \est{\mmu} \convp \true\mmu\est\mmu\convp\true\mmu(3.32)
(3.33)n(\est\mmu−\true\mmu)\convd\Normd(\zz,J−1(\true\mmu)TK(\true\mmu)J−1(\true\mmu))\tag{3.33} \sqrt{n}(\est{\mmu} - \true\mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, J^{-1}(\true\mmu)^TK(\true\mmu)J^{-1}(\true\mmu))n​(\est\mmu−\true\mmu)\convd\Normd​(\zz,J−1(\true\mmu)TK(\true\mmu)J−1(\true\mmu))(3.33)

Unit 4: Hypothesis testing

Lecture 13: Chi Squared Distribution, T-Test

Our previous tests were based on the CLT and Slutsky.

  • What if Slutsky does not apply?
  • Can we use asymptotic normality of the MLE?
  • How about tests with multivariate parameters (e.g. θ1=θ2\theta_1 = \theta_2θ1​=θ2​)?
  • Can we more general tests, such as "is my distribution Gaussian"?

Example: Pharmaceutical company wants to test if a new drug is efficient. They administer a drug to a group of patients (test group) and a placebo to another (control group). We want to test if the drugs lowers LDL (bad cholersterol) among patients with a high level of LDL.

  • Let Δd>0\Delta_d > 0Δd​>0 denote the expected decrease of LDL level for a patient in the test group.
  • Let Δc≥0\Delta_c \geq 0Δc​≥0 denote the expected decrease of LDL level for a patient in the control group.
  • We want to know if Δd>Δc\Delta_d > \Delta_cΔd​>Δc​; we observe:
    • X1,…,Xn\iid\Norm(Δd,σd2)X_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \Norm(\Delta_d, \sigma_d^2)X1​,…,Xn​\iid\Norm(Δd​,σd2​) from the test group,
    • Y1,…,Ym\iid\Norm(Δc,σc2)Y_1, \ldots, Y_m \iid \Norm(\Delta_c, \sigma_c^2)Y1​,…,Ym​\iid\Norm(Δc​,σc2​) from the control group.

Our hypothesis testing is:

H0:Δc≤Δd,H1:Δd>ΔcH_0: \Delta_c \leq \Delta_d, H_1: \Delta_d > \Delta_cH0​:Δc​≤Δd​,H1​:Δd​>Δc​

As the data is Gaussian,

Xˉn∼\Norm(Δd,σd2n),Yˉm∼\Norm(Δc,σc2m)\bar{X}_n \sim \Norm\left(\Delta_d, \frac{\sigma_d^2}n\right), \bar{Y}_m \sim \Norm\left(\Delta_c, \frac{\sigma_c^2}m\right)Xˉn​∼\Norm(Δd​,nσd2​​),Yˉm​∼\Norm(Δc​,mσc2​​)

Therefore,

Xˉn−Yˉm−(Δd−Δc)σd2/n+σc2/m∼\Norm(0,1)\frac{\bar{X}_n - \bar{Y}_m - (\Delta_d - \Delta_c)}{\sqrt{\sigma_d^2/n + \sigma_c^2/m}} \sim \Norm(0, 1)σd2​/n+σc2​/m​Xˉn​−Yˉm​−(Δd​−Δc​)​∼\Norm(0,1)

Using Slutsky,

Xˉn−Yˉm−(Δd−Δc)σ^d2/n+σ^c2/m∼\Norm(0,1)\frac{\bar{X}_n - \bar{Y}_m - (\Delta_d - \Delta_c)}{\sqrt{\hat{\sigma}_d^2/n + \hat{\sigma}_c^2/m}} \sim \Norm(0, 1)σ^d2​/n+σ^c2​/m​Xˉn​−Yˉm​−(Δd​−Δc​)​∼\Norm(0,1)

Where

σ^d2=1n−1∑i=1n(Xi−Xˉn)2,σ^c2=1m−1∑i=1m(Yi−Yˉm)2\hat{\sigma}^2_d = \frac1{n-1}\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-\bar{X}_n)^2, \hat{\sigma}^2_c = \frac1{m-1}\sum_{i=1}^m(Y_i-\bar{Y}_m)^2σ^d2​=n−11​i=1∑n​(Xi​−Xˉn​)2,σ^c2​=m−11​i=1∑m​(Yi​−Yˉm​)2

Therefore, the test with asymptotic level α\alphaα is given by:

Rψ={Xˉn−Yˉmσ^d2/n+σ^c2/m>qα}R_\psi = \left\{\frac{\bar{X}_n - \bar{Y}_m}{\sqrt{\hat{\sigma}^2_d/n + \hat{\sigma}^2_c/m}} > q_\alpha\right\}Rψ​={σ^d2​/n+σ^c2​/m​Xˉn​−Yˉm​​>qα​}

If n,mn, mn,m are small, we cannot realistically apply Slutsky.

Let d∈Nd \in \Nd∈N.

The χ2\chi^2χ2 distribution with ddd degrees of freedom is the law of the random variable

(4.1)Z12+Z22+…+Zd2\tag{4.1}Z_1^2 + Z_2^2 + \ldots + Z_d^2Z12​+Z22​+…+Zd2​(4.1)

where Z1,…,Zd\iid\Norm(0,1)Z_1, \ldots, Z_d \iid \Norm(0, 1)Z1​,…,Zd​\iid\Norm(0,1).

If Z∼\Normd(0,Id)Z \sim \Norm_d(0, I_d)Z∼\Normd​(0,Id​), then ∥Z∥n2∼χd2\|Z\|^2_n \sim \chi^2_d∥Z∥n2​∼χd2​.

χ22=Exp(1/2)\chi^2_2 = \mathcal{Exp}(1/2)χ22​=Exp(1/2).

If V∼χk2V \sim \chi^2_kV∼χk2​, then:

  • \E[V]=\E[Z12]+…+\E[Zd2]=d\E[V] = \E[Z_1^2] + \ldots + \E[Z_d^2] = d\E[V]=\E[Z12​]+…+\E[Zd2​]=d
  • \V[V]=\V[Z12]+…+\E[Zd2]=2d\V[V] = \V[Z_1^2] + \ldots + \E[Z_d^2] = 2d\V[V]=\V[Z12​]+…+\E[Zd2​]=2d

Cochran's Theorem: for X1,…,Xn\iid\Norm(μ,σ2)X_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X1​,…,Xn​\iid\Norm(μ,σ2), if SnS_nSn​ is the sample variance defined as

(4.2)Sn=1n∑i=1n(Xi−Xˉn)2=1n∑i=1nXi2−Xˉn2\tag{4.2}S_n = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i - \bar{X}_n)^2 = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^nX_i^2 - \bar{X}_n^2Sn​=n1​i=1∑n​(Xi​−Xˉn​)2=n1​i=1∑n​Xi2​−Xˉn2​(4.2)

(4.3)Xˉn⊥​​​⊥Sn\tag{4.3} \bar{X}_n \perp\!\!\!\perp S_nXˉn​⊥⊥Sn​(4.3)

\E[S~n]=nn−1\E[σ2nχn−12]=nn−1σ2\fran−1n=σ2\E[\tilde{S}_n] = \frac{n}{n-1}\E\left[\frac{\sigma^2}n\chi^2_{n-1}\right] = \frac{n}{n-1}\sigma^2\fra{n-1}n = \sigma^2\E[S~n​]=n−1n​\E[nσ2​χn−12​]=n−1n​σ2\fran−1n=σ2

The Student's T test can be used for any size of samples, even for very small samples; however, it relies on the assumption that the sample is Gaussian.

Implicit hypotheses: let X1,…,Xn\iid\PX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​\iid\P, and let \ttheta∈Rd\ttheta \in \R^d\ttheta∈Rd be a parameter associated with \P\P\P. Let g:Rd→Rkg: \R^d \rightarrow \R^kg:Rd→Rk be continuously differentiable, with k≤dk \leq dk≤d. Let us consider:

n(\tthn−\ttheta)\convd\Normd(0,\SSigma(\ttheta))\sqrt{n}(\tthn - \ttheta) \convd \Norm_d(0, \SSigma(\ttheta))n​(\tthn−\ttheta)\convd\Normd​(0,\SSigma(\ttheta))

n(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk(\zz,Γ(\ttheta))\sqrt{n}(g(\tthn) - g(\ttheta)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, \Gamma(\ttheta))n​(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk​(\zz,Γ(\ttheta))

where Γ(\ttheta)=\Nablag(\ttheta)T\SSigma(\ttheta)\Nablag(\ttheta)∈Rk×k\Gamma(\ttheta) = \Nabla g(\ttheta)^T\SSigma(\ttheta)\Nabla g(\ttheta) \in \R^{k\times k}Γ(\ttheta)=\Nablag(\ttheta)T\SSigma(\ttheta)\Nablag(\ttheta)∈Rk×k. If \SSigma(\ttheta)\SSigma(\ttheta)\SSigma(\ttheta) is invertible and \Nablag(\ttheta)\Nabla g(\ttheta)\Nablag(\ttheta) has rank kkk, then Γ(\ttheta)\Gamma(\ttheta)Γ(\ttheta) is invertible and

(4.16)nΓ(\ttheta)−1/2(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk(\zz,Ik)\tag{4.16}\sqrt{n}\Gamma(\ttheta)^{-1/2}(g(\tthn) - g(\ttheta)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, I_k)n​Γ(\ttheta)−1/2(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk​(\zz,Ik​)(4.16)

Then, by applying the Slutsky theorem, if Γ(\ttheta)\Gamma(\ttheta)Γ(\ttheta) is continuous, then

nΓ(\tthn)−1/2(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk(\zz,Ik)\sqrt{n}\Gamma(\tthn)^{-1/2}(g(\tthn) - g(\ttheta)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, I_k)n​Γ(\tthn)−1/2(g(\tthn)−g(\ttheta))\convd\Normk​(\zz,Ik​)

Hence, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then:

(4.17)Tn=ng(\tthn)TΓ(\tthn)−1g(\tthn)\convdχk2\tag{4.17}T_n = ng(\tthn)^T\Gamma(\tthn)^{-1}g(\tthn) \convd \chi^2_kTn​=ng(\tthn)TΓ(\tthn)−1g(\tthn)\convdχk2​(4.17)

The test with asymptotic level α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1) is therefore given by:

(4.18)ψα=\one{Tn>qα}\tag{4.18} \psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha\}ψα​=\one{Tn​>qα​}(4.18)

where qαq_\alphaqα​ is the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α)-quantile of χk2\chi^2_kχk2​.

Let XXX be a r.v. Given i.i.d copies of XXX, we want to answer the following type of questions:

  • Does XXX have a normal distribution?
  • Does XXX have a uniform distribution?
  • Does XXX have this PMF?

This class of questions is called goodness of fit (GoF) tests: we want to know if the hypothesized distribution is a good fit for the data.

let E={a1,…,aK}E = \{a_1, \ldots, a_K\}E={a1​,…,aK​} be a finite space, and (\P\pp)\pp∈ΔK(\P_\pp)_{\pp \in \Delta_K}(\P\pp​)\pp∈ΔK​​ the family of all probability distributions on EEE, where:

ΔK={\pp∈(0,1)K,∑i=1Kpi=1}\Delta_K = \left\{\pp \in (0, 1)^K, \sum_{i=1}^Kp_i = 1\right\}ΔK​={\pp∈(0,1)K,i=1∑K​pi​=1}

For \pp∈ΔK\pp \in \Delta_K\pp∈ΔK​ and X∼\P\ppX \sim \P_\ppX∼\P\pp​,

∀1≤i≤K,\P\pp[X=ai]=pi\forall 1 \leq i \leq K, \P_\pp[X = a_i] = p_i∀1≤i≤K,\P\pp​[X=ai​]=pi​

Let X1,…,Xn\iid\P\ppX_1, \ldots, X_n \iid \P_\ppX1​,…,Xn​\iid\P\pp​ for some unknown \pp∈Δk\pp \in \Delta_k\pp∈Δk​, and let \pp0∈Δk\pp^0 \in \Delta_k\pp0∈Δk​ be fixed. We want to test:

H0:\pp=\pp0,H1:\pp≠\pp0H_0: \pp = \pp^0, H_1: \pp \neq \pp^0H0​:\pp=\pp0,H1​:\pp̸​=\pp0

Le likelihood of the multinomial model is given by:

(4.19)Ln(x1,…,xn,\pp)=∏i=1KpiNi\tag{4.19}L_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n, \pp) = \prod_{i=1}^Kp_i^{N_i}Ln​(x1​,…,xn​,\pp)=i=1∏K​piNi​​(4.19)

where Ni=∣{Xj=ai,1≤j≤n}∣N_i = |\{X_j = a_i, 1 \leq j \leq n\}|Ni​=∣{Xj​=ai​,1≤j≤n}∣. Let \est\pp\est{\pp}\est\pp be the MLE:

(\est\pp)i=Njn(\est{\pp})_i = \frac{N_j}{n}(\est\pp)i​=nNj​​

However, \est\pp\est{\pp}\est\pp maximizes ℓn\ell_nℓn​ under the constraint ∑ipi=1\sum_i p_i = 1∑i​pi​=1.

If H0H_0H0​ is true, then n(\est\pp−\pp0)\sqrt{n}(\est{\pp} - \pp^0)n​(\est\pp−\pp0) is asymptotically normal, and the following holds:

nI(\pp0)1/2(\est\pp−\pp0)\convd\NormK−1(0,IK−1)\sqrt{n}I(\pp^0)^{1/2}(\est{\pp} - \pp^0) \convd \Norm_{K-1}(0, I_{K-1})n​I(\pp0)1/2(\est\pp−\pp0)\convd\NormK−1​(0,IK−1​)

Theorem: under H0H_0H0​,

(4.20)Tn=n∑i=1K((\est\pp)i−\ppi0)2\ppi0\convdχK−12\tag{4.20}T_n = n\sum_{i=1}^K\frac{((\est{\pp})_i - \pp^0_i)^2}{\pp^0_i} \convd \chi^2_{K-1}Tn​=ni=1∑K​\ppi0​((\est\pp)i​−\ppi0​)2​\convdχK−12​(4.20)

The χ2\chi^2χ2 test with asymptotic level α\alphaα is given by:

(4.21)ψα=\one{Tn>qα}\tag{4.21}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha\}ψα​=\one{Tn​>qα​}(4.21)

where qαq_\alphaqα​ is the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α)-quantile of χK−12\chi^2_{K-1}χK−12​. The asymptotic p-value is given by:

(4.22)\P[Z>Tn∣Tn]\tag{4.22} \P[Z > T_n | T_n]\P[Z>Tn​∣Tn​](4.22)

where Z∼χK−12Z \sim \chi^2_{K-1}Z∼χK−12​ and Z⊥​​​⊥TnZ \perp\!\!\!\perp T_nZ⊥⊥Tn​.

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be i.i.d real random variables. The CDF of XXX is defined as:

∀t∈R,F(t)=\P[X≤t]\forall t \in \R, F(t) = \P[X \leq t]∀t∈R,F(t)=\P[X≤t]

It completely characterizes the distribution of XXX.

The empirical CDF of X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ is defined as:

(4.23)∀t∈R,Fn(t)=1n∑i=1n\one{Xi≤t}=∣{Xi≤t,1≤i≤n}∣n\tag{4.23}\begin{aligned}\displaystyle \forall t \in \R, F_n(t) &= \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\one\{X_i \leq t\} \\ &= \displaystyle \frac{|\{X_i \leq t, 1 \leq i \leq n\}|}n\end{aligned}∀t∈R,Fn​(t)​=n1​i=1∑n​\one{Xi​≤t}=n∣{Xi​≤t,1≤i≤n}∣​​(4.23)

By the LLN,

(4.24)Fn(t)\convasF(t)\tag{4.24}F_n(t) \convas F(t)Fn​(t)\convasF(t)(4.24)

Glivenko-Cantelli Theorem:

(4.25)sup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F(t)∣\convas0\tag{4.25}\sup_{t\in\R}|F_n(t)-F(t)| \convas 0t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F(t)∣\convas0(4.25)

By the CLT:

(4.26)∀t∈R,n(Fn(t)−F(t))\convd\Norm(0,F(t)(1−F(t)))\tag{4.26}\forall t \in \R, \sqrt{n}(F_n(t) - F(t)) \convd \Norm(0, F(t)(1-F(t)))∀t∈R,n​(Fn​(t)−F(t))\convd\Norm(0,F(t)(1−F(t)))(4.26)

Donsker's Theorem: if FFF is continuous, then

(4.27)nsup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F(t)∣\convdsup⁡t∈[0,1]∣\B(t)∣\tag{4.27}\sqrt{n}\sup_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - F(t)| \convd \sup_{t \in [0, 1]}|\B(t)|n​t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F(t)∣\convdt∈[0,1]sup​∣\B(t)∣(4.27)

where \B\B\B is a Brownian bridge on [0,1][0, 1][0,1].

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be i.i.d real random variables with unknown CDF FFF and let F0F^0F0 be a continuous CDF. Let us consider

H0:F=F0,H1:F≠F0H_0: F = F^0, H_1: F \neq F^0H0​:F=F0,H1​:F̸​=F0

Let FnF_nFn​ be the empirical CDF of the sample X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​. If H0H_0H0​ is true, then ∀t∈R,Fn(t)≈F0(t)\forall t \in \R, F_n(t) \approx F^0(t)∀t∈R,Fn​(t)≈F0(t).

Let

(4.28)Tn=sup⁡t∈Rn∣Fn(t)−F0(t)∣\tag{4.28}T_n = \sup_{t \in \R}\sqrt{n}|F_n(t) - F^0(t)|Tn​=t∈Rsup​n​∣Fn​(t)−F0(t)∣(4.28)

Then, by Donsker's theorem, if H0H_0H0​ is rtue, then Tn\convdZT_n \convd ZTn​\convdZ, where ZZZ has a known distribution, the supremum of an absolute Brownian bridge.

The Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test with asymptotic level α\alphaα is given by:

(4.29)δαKS=\one{Tn>qα}\tag{4.29}\delta_\alpha^{KS} = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha\}δαKS​=\one{Tn​>qα​}(4.29)

where qαq_\alphaqα​ is the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α)-quantile of ZZZ. The p-value of the KS test is given by \P[Z>Tn∣Tn]\P[Z > T_n | T_n]\P[Z>Tn​∣Tn​].

In practice, how to compute TnT_nTn​? The expression of TnT_nTn​ reduces to the following formula:

(4.30)Tn=nmax⁡1≤i≤n{max⁡(∣i−1n−F0(X(i))∣,∣in−F0(X(i))∣)}\tag{4.30}T_n = \sqrt{n}\max_{1 \leq i \leq n}\left\{\max\left(\left|\frac{i-1}n - F^0(X_{(i)})\right|, \left|\frac{i}n - F^0(X_{(i)})\right|\right)\right\}Tn​=n​1≤i≤nmax​{max(∣∣∣∣​ni−1​−F0(X(i)​)∣∣∣∣​,∣∣∣∣​ni​−F0(X(i)​)∣∣∣∣​)}(4.30)

where X(1)≤…≤X(n)X_{(1)} \leq \ldots \leq X_{(n)}X(1)​≤…≤X(n)​ are the reordered samples.

TnT_nTn​ is called a pivotal statistic. If H0H_0H0​ is true, the distribution of TnT_nTn​ does not depend on the distribution of the XiX_iXi​'s and it is easy to reproduce it in simulations. Indeed, let Ui=F0(Xi)U_i = F^0(X_i)Ui​=F0(Xi​), and GnG_nGn​ the empirical CDF of UUU. If H0H_0H0​ is true, then

U1,…,Un\iidU(0,1),Tn=∑x∈[0,1]n∣Gn(x)−x∣U_1, \ldots, U_n \iid \mathcal{U}(0, 1), T_n = \sum_{x \in [0, 1]}\sqrt{n}|G_n(x) - x|U1​,…,Un​\iidU(0,1),Tn​=x∈[0,1]∑​n​∣Gn​(x)−x∣

Hence, for some large integer MMM:

  • simulate MMM i.i.d copies Tn1,…,TnMT^1_n, \ldots, T^M_nTn1​,…,TnM​ of TnT_nTn​,
  • estimate the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α)-quantile qα(n)q_\alpha^{(n)}qα(n)​ of TnT_nTn​ by taking the sample (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α)-quantile q^α\hat{q}_\alpha%{(n, M)}q^​α​ of Tn1,…,TnMT^1_n, \ldots, T^M_nTn1​,…,TnM​,
  • Test with approximate level α\alphaα:
δα≈\one{Tn>q^α\delta_\alpha \approx \one\{T_n > \hat{q}_\alpha%{(n, M)}}δα​≈\one{Tn​>q^​α​

The p-value of the test is given by:

\pval≈1M∣{Tni>Tn,1≤i≤M}∣\pval \approx \frac1M|\{T_n^i > T_n, 1 \leq i \leq M\}|\pval≈M1​∣{Tni​>Tn​,1≤i≤M}∣

We want to measure the distance between two functions Fn(t)F_n(t)Fn​(t) and F(t)F(t)F(t):

Kolmogorov-Smirnov:

(4.31)d(Fn,F)=sup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F(t)∣\tag{4.31}d(F_n, F) = \sup_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - F(t)|d(Fn​,F)=t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F(t)∣(4.31)

Cramér-Von Mises:

(4.32)d2(Fn,F)=∫R(Fn(t)−F(t))2dF(t)=\EF[(Fn(X)−F(X))2]\tag{4.32}d^2(F_n, F) = \int_\R\left(F_n(t) - F(t)\right)^2dF(t) = \E_F[(F_n(X) - F(X))^2]d2(Fn​,F)=∫R​(Fn​(t)−F(t))2dF(t)=\EF​[(Fn​(X)−F(X))2](4.32)

Anderson-Darling:

$$\tag{4.33}d^2(F_n, F) = \int_\R\frac{(F_n(t) - F(t))^2}{F(t)(1-F(t))}dF(t)

If I want to test if XXX has a Gaussian distribution, but without knowing the parameters, let us use plug-in:

(4.34)∑t∈R∣Fn(t)−Φ\estμ,\estσ2(t)∣\tag{4.34}\sum_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - \Phi_{\est{\mu}, \est{\sigma^2}}(t)|t∈R∑​∣Fn​(t)−Φ\estμ,\estσ2​(t)∣(4.34)

Where \estμ=Xˉn\est{\mu} = \bar{X}_n\estμ=Xˉn​ and \estσ2=Sn2\est{\sigma^2} = S_n^2\estσ2=Sn2​, and Φμ,σ2\Phi_{\mu, \sigma^2}Φμ,σ2​ is the CDF of \Norm(μ,σ2)\Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)\Norm(μ,σ2).

In this case, Donsker's theorem is no longer valid. This is a very common and serious mistake!

Kolmogorov-Lilliefors test: instead, we compute the quantils for the test statistic:

∑t∈R∣Fn(t)−Φ\estμ,\estσ2(t)∣\sum_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - \Phi_{\est{\mu}, \est{\sigma^2}}(t)|t∈R∑​∣Fn​(t)−Φ\estμ,\estσ2​(t)∣

They do not depend on unknown parameters!

Quantile-Quantile (QQ) plots: they provide a visual way to perform G-F tests. It's a quick and easy check to see if a distribution is plausible. The main idea is to check visually if the plot of FnF_nFn​ is close to that of FFF, or equivalently if the plot of Fn−1F_n^{-1}Fn−1​ is close to that of F−1F^{-1}F−1.

The test consists on checking whether the points

(4.34)(F−1(1n),Fn−1(1n)),(F−1(2n),Fn−1(2n)),…,(F−1(n−1n),Fn−1(n−1n))\tag{4.34}\left(F^{-1}\left(\frac1n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac1n\right)\right), \left(F^{-1}\left(\frac2n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac2n\right)\right), \ldots, \left(F^{-1}\left(\frac{n-1}n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac{n-1}n\right)\right)(F−1(n1​),Fn−1​(n1​)),(F−1(n2​),Fn−1​(n2​)),…,(F−1(nn−1​),Fn−1​(nn−1​))(4.34)

are aligned along y=xy = xy=x. FnF_nFn​ is not technically invertible, but we define

(4.35)Fn−1(in)=X(i)\tag{4.35}F_n^{-1}\left(\frac{i}n\right) = X_{(i)}Fn−1​(ni​)=X(i)​(4.35)

where X(i)X_{(i)}X(i)​ are the ordered samples.

(A.5.1)fa,b(x)=1b−a\one{a≤x≤b}\tag{A.5.1} f_{a, b}(x) = \frac1{b-a}\one\{a \leq x \leq b\}fa,b​(x)=b−a1​\one{a≤x≤b}(A.5.1)

(A.5.2)Fa,b(x)={0ifx<ax−ab−aifa≤x≤b1ifx>b\tag{A.5.2} F_{a, b}(x) = \begin{cases}\displaystyle 0 & \text{if}\quad x < a \\ \displaystyle \frac{x-a}{b-a} & \text{if}\quad a \leq x \leq b \\ \displaystyle 1 & \text{if}\quad x > b \end{cases}Fa,b​(x)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​0b−ax−a​1​ifx<aifa≤x≤bifx>b​(A.5.2)

Addendum B: Notable relations

Statistics

Probability, density and expectation

A probability space is a triplet (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)(Ω,F,P) where Ω\OmegaΩ is the set of possible outcomes, F\mathcal{F}F a set of subsets of Ω\OmegaΩ such as (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathcal{F})(Ω,F) is measurable and P:F→[0,1]P: \mathcal{F} \rightarrow [0, 1]P:F→[0,1] is the probability function such as it is (countably) additive and $P (\Omega) = 1$.

A random variable XXX is a function:

(B.1.1)X:Ω→E\tag{B.1.1}X: \Omega \rightarrow EX:Ω→E(B.1.1)

Where EEE is the value-space of XXX; usually, E⊆RE \subseteq \RE⊆R. For any S⊆ES \subseteq ES⊆E, the probability of X∈SX \in SX∈S is given by:

(B.1.2)\P[X∈S]=P({ω∈Ω∣X(ω)∈S})\tag{B.1.2}\P[X \in S] = P(\{\omega \in \Omega | X(\omega) \in S\})\P[X∈S]=P({ω∈Ω∣X(ω)∈S})(B.1.2)

If EEE is discrete, we can define the Probability Mass Function (PMF) pX:E→[0,1]p_X: E \rightarrow [0,1]pX​:E→[0,1] of XXX:

(B.1.3)∀x∈E,pX(x)=\P[X=x]=P({X−1(x)})\tag{B.1.3}\forall x \in E, p_X(x) = \P[X = x] = P(\{X^{-1}(x)\})∀x∈E,pX​(x)=\P[X=x]=P({X−1(x)})(B.1.3)

If E⊆RE \subseteq \RE⊆R, we can defin the Cumulative Density Function (CDF) FX:E→[0,1]F_X: E \rightarrow [0,1]FX​:E→[0,1] of XXX:

(B.1.4)∀x∈E,FX(x)=\P[X≤x]=P(X−1((−∞,x])))\tag{B.1.4}\forall x \in E, F_X(x) = \P[X \leq x] = P(X^{-1}((-\infty, x])))∀x∈E,FX​(x)=\P[X≤x]=P(X−1((−∞,x])))(B.1.4)

And the Probability Density Function (PDF) fX:E→[0,+∞)f_X: E \rightarrow [0,+\infty)fX​:E→[0,+∞) is defined by:

(B.1.5)fX(x)=FX′(x)\tag{B.1.5}f_X(x) = F_X'(x)fX​(x)=FX′​(x)(B.1.5)

Which leads to the following relation:

(B.1.6)∫abfX(x)dx=FX(b)−FX(a)=\P[X≤b]−\P[X≤a]=\P[x∈[a,b]]=P(X−1([a,b]))\tag{B.1.6}\int_a^bf_X(x)dx = F_X(b) - F_X(a) = \P[X \leq b] - \P[X \leq a] = \P[x \in [a,b]] = P(X^{-1}([a,b]))∫ab​fX​(x)dx=FX​(b)−FX​(a)=\P[X≤b]−\P[X≤a]=\P[x∈[a,b]]=P(X−1([a,b]))(B.1.6)

The expectation of a random variable XXX is defined as:

(B.1.7)\E[X]=∫ΩX(ω)dP(ω)=∫01xdFX(x)=∫ExfX(x)dx\tag{B.1.7} \E[X] = \int_\Omega X(\omega)dP(\omega) = \int_0^1xdF_X(x) = \int_Exf_X(x)dx\E[X]=∫Ω​X(ω)dP(ω)=∫01​xdFX​(x)=∫E​xfX​(x)dx(B.1.7)

Given a function g:E→F⊆Rg : E \rightarrow F \subseteq \Rg:E→F⊆R bijective and continuously differentiable, and Y=g(X)Y = g(X)Y=g(X), then

(B.1.8)FY(y)=\P[Y≤y]=\P[g(X)≤g(x)]={\P[X≤x]=FX(x) if g is increasing\P[X≥x]==1−FX(x) if g is decreasing\tag{B.1.8}F_Y(y) = \P[Y \leq y] = \P[g(X) \leq g(x)] = \begin{cases} \P[X \leq x] = F_X(x) & \text{ if }g\text{ is increasing} \\ \P[X \geq x] = = 1 - F_X(x) & \text{ if }g\text{ is decreasing} \end{cases}FY​(y)=\P[Y≤y]=\P[g(X)≤g(x)]={\P[X≤x]=FX​(x)\P[X≥x]==1−FX​(x)​ if g is increasing if g is decreasing​(B.1.8)

Therefore:

fY(y)=\diffFYy(y)={\diffFXy(y)=\diffxy(y)\diffFXx(x)=(g−1)′(y)fX(x) if g is increasing\diff1−FXy(y)=\diffxy(y)\diff1−FXx(x)=−(g−1)′(y)fX(x) if g is decreasingf_Y(y) = \diff{F_Y}{y}(y) =\begin{cases} \displaystyle \diff{F_X}{y}(y) = \diff{x}{y}(y)\diff{F_X}{x}(x) = (g^{-1})'(y)f_X(x) & \text{ if }g\text{ is increasing} \\ \displaystyle \diff{1-F_X}{y}(y) = \diff{x}{y}(y)\diff{1-F_X}{x}(x) = -(g^{-1})'(y)f_X(x) & \text{ if }g\text{ is decreasing} \end{cases}fY​(y)=\diffFY​y(y)={\diffFX​y(y)=\diffxy(y)\diffFX​x(x)=(g−1)′(y)fX​(x)\diff1−FX​y(y)=\diffxy(y)\diff1−FX​x(x)=−(g−1)′(y)fX​(x)​ if g is increasing if g is decreasing​

Which means:

(B.1.9)fY(y)=∣(g−1)′(y)∣fX(x)\tag{B.1.9}f_Y(y) = |(g^{-1})'(y)|f_X(x)fY​(y)=∣(g−1)′(y)∣fX​(x)(B.1.9)

Combining this result with the change of variable y=g(x)y = g(x)y=g(x) yields the Law of the Unconscious Statistician:

(B.1.10)\E[g(X)]=∫01ydFY(y)=∫Eg(x)fX(x)dx\tag{B.1.10}\E[g(X)] = \int_0^1ydF_Y(y) = \int_Eg(x)f_X(x)dx\E[g(X)]=∫01​ydFY​(y)=∫E​g(x)fX​(x)dx(B.1.10)

Expectation properties, given X,YX, YX,Y random variables and a,b∈Ra, b \in \Ra,b∈R:

(B.1.11){X=a.s.Y  ⟹  \E[X]=\E[Y]X=a.s.c∈E  ⟹  \E[X]=c\E[\E[X]]=\E[X]\E[aX+bY]=a\E[X]+b\E[Y]\tag{B.1.11} \begin{cases} X \overset{a.s.}{=} Y \implies \E[X] = \E[Y] \\ X \overset{a.s.}{=} c \in E \implies \E[X] = c \\ \E[\E[X]] = \E[X] \\ \E[aX + bY] = a\E[X] + b\E[Y] \end{cases}⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​X=a.s.Y⟹\E[X]=\E[Y]X=a.s.c∈E⟹\E[X]=c\E[\E[X]]=\E[X]\E[aX+bY]=a\E[X]+b\E[Y]​(B.1.11)

Jensen's Inequality, given a function ϕ\phiϕ convex:

(B.1.12)φ(\E[X])≤\E[φ(X)]\tag{B.1.12}\varphi(\E[X]) \leq \E[\varphi(X)]φ(\E[X])≤\E[φ(X)](B.1.12)

Variance and Independence

The variance of a random variable XXX is defined by:

(B.1.13)\V[X]=\E[(X−\E[X])2]=\E[X2−2X\E[X]+\E[X]2]=\E[X2]−2\E[X]\E[X]+\E[X]2=\E[X2]−\E[X]2\tag{B.1.13}\V[X] = \E[(X - \E[X])^2] = \E[X^2 - 2X\E[X] + \E[X]^2] = \E[X^2] - 2\E[X]\E[X] + \E[X]^2 = \E[X^2] - \E[X]^2\V[X]=\E[(X−\E[X])2]=\E[X2−2X\E[X]+\E[X]2]=\E[X2]−2\E[X]\E[X]+\E[X]2=\E[X2]−\E[X]2(B.1.13)

Variance properties, with XXX a random variable and a∈Ra \in \Ra∈R:

$$\tag{B.1.14}\begin{cases} \V[X + a] = \V[X] \V[aX] = a^2\V[X]

The covariance of two random variables XXX and YYY is defined by:

(B.1.15)\Cov(X,Y)=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[(X−\E[X])Y]\tag{B.1.15}\Cov(X, Y) = \E[(X - \E[X])(Y - \E[Y])] = \E[XY] - \E[X]\E[Y] = \E[X(Y - \E[Y])] = \E[(X - \E[X])Y]\Cov(X,Y)=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[(X−\E[X])Y](B.1.15)

In particular,

(B.1.16)\Cov(X,X)=\V[X]\tag{B.1.16}\Cov(X, X) = \V[X]\Cov(X,X)=\V[X](B.1.16)

Covariance properties, with X,Y,ZX, Y, ZX,Y,Z random variables, and a,b,c∈Ra, b, c \in \Ra,b,c∈R:

(B.1.17){\Cov(X,a)=0\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)\Cov(aX+bY,cZ)=ac\Cov(X,Z)+bc\Cov(Y,Z)\tag{B.1.17}\begin{cases} \Cov(X, a) = 0 \\ \Cov(X, Y) = \Cov(Y, X) \\ \Cov(aX + bY, cZ) = ac\Cov(X, Z) + bc\Cov(Y, Z) \end{cases}⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​\Cov(X,a)=0\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)\Cov(aX+bY,cZ)=ac\Cov(X,Z)+bc\Cov(Y,Z)​(B.1.17)

In particular,

(B.1.18)\V[X+Y]=\V[X]+\V[Y]+2\Cov(X,Y)\tag{B.1.18}\V[X+Y] = \V[X] + \V[Y] + 2\Cov(X, Y)\V[X+Y]=\V[X]+\V[Y]+2\Cov(X,Y)(B.1.18)

Two random variables X,YX, YX,Y are independent (X⊥​​​⊥YX \perp \!\!\! \perp YX⊥⊥Y) if

(B.1.18)X⊥​​​⊥Y  ⟺  FX,Y(x,y)=FX(x)FY(y)  ⟺  fX,Y(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y)\tag{B.1.18}X \perp \!\!\! \perp Y \iff F_{X,Y}(x, y) = F_X(x)F_Y(y) \iff f_{X,Y}(x,y) = f_X(x)f_Y(y)X⊥⊥Y⟺FX,Y​(x,y)=FX​(x)FY​(y)⟺fX,Y​(x,y)=fX​(x)fY​(y)(B.1.18)

Therefore, if X⊥​​​⊥YX \perp\!\!\!\perp YX⊥⊥Y, then

(B.1.19)\E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y]\tag{B.1.19} \E[XY] = \E[X]\E[Y]\E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y](B.1.19)

But the converse isn't true in general. It follows that:

(B.1.20){\Cov(X,Y)=0\V[X+Y]=\V[X]+\V[Y]\tag{B.1.20}\begin{cases} \Cov(X, Y) = 0 \\ \V[X+Y] = \V[X] + \V[Y] \end{cases}{\Cov(X,Y)=0\V[X+Y]=\V[X]+\V[Y]​(B.1.20)

Tests

The p-value is formally defined as:

(B.1.21)\pval=\P[D≥Tn∣Tn]\tag{B.1.21} \pval = \P[\mathcal{D} \geq T_n | T_n]\pval=\P[D≥Tn​∣Tn​](B.1.21)

Where TnT_nTn​ is the test statistics and D\mathcal{D}D is the test distribution (\Norm(0,1)\Norm(0,1)\Norm(0,1) for an asymptotic test).

Probability

Conditional Probability

Given two events A,B⊂ΩA, B \subset \OmegaA,B⊂Ω, the conditional probabilty of AAA knowing BBB is defined as:

(B.2.1)P(A∣B)=P(A∩B)P(B)≤1\tag{B.2.1}P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} \leq 1P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​≤1(B.2.1)

The Bayes Formula gives us an expression of this probability:

(B.2.2)P(A∣B)=P(A)P(B∣A)P(B)\tag{B.2.2}P(A|B) = \frac{P(A)P(B|A)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A)P(B∣A)​(B.2.2)

AAA and BBB are independent if

(B.2.3)P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B)\tag{B.2.3}P(A\cap B) = P(A)P(B)P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B)(B.2.3)

Which leads to:

(B.2.4)P(A∣B)=P(A),P(B∣A)=P(B)\tag{B.2.4}P(A|B) = P(A), P(B|A) = P(B)P(A∣B)=P(A),P(B∣A)=P(B)(B.2.4)
